sources.title: Intricate behavior of winter pollution in Hanoi over the 2006–2020 semi-climatic period
Effects of local, regional meteorology and emission sources on mass and compositions of particulate matter in Hanoi
Trans-boundary air pollution in a Southeast Asian megacity: Case studies of the synoptic meteorological mechanisms and impacts on air quality
The Cross-Border Transport of PM2.5 from the Southeast Asian Biomass Burning Emissions and Its Impact on Air Pollution in Yunnan Plateau, Southwest China
Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities
Chemical composition and potential sources of PM2.5 in Hanoi

causal_relationships.evidence_quote: long-range transport from China during the onset of cold surges caused an average increase of around 30% of the PM2.5 level in Hanoi
The stagnation of local pollution during the cold surges persistence causes an average increase of ~40% in level of PM2.5

causal_relationships.effect: Pollution transport from Eastern China and Red River Delta
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: During regular winters, northeastern air masses predominated, which can bring pollution from eastern China and the industrial region surrounding Hanoi (Red River Delta)

causal_relationships.effect: Change in pollution sources (decrease sulfate AOD, increase smoke AOD)
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: the existence of El Niño perturbed the air masses trajectories during three winters (2014/15, 2015/16 and 2018/19), bringing more western air masses
High 24 h PM levels were observed at low wind speeds when a stagnating ridge governed over Northern Vietnam

causal_relationships.cause: Wind direction relative to emission sources
conditions: Wind direction aligned with emission sources
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: The daily PM2.5 levels were found to closely link to local wind speeds and directions (relative to local emission sources)

Anthropogenic PM2.5 emissions in continental East Asia fed the 2013 event, which was then transported by strong northeasterly winds triggered by an upper-level ridge near the Tibetan Plateau and a low-pressure system in western Pacific Ocean

causal_relationships.cause: El Niño + Western Pacific Subtropical High
causal_relationships.effect: Indonesia biomass burning transport to Vietnam
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: the 2015 event was the result of Indonesia biomass burning (BB), which was enhanced and transported by a westward propagating Western Pacific Subtropical High triggered by a strong El Niño event
East Asian monsoon activity in winter drives much of the transboundary air pollution from China and significantly impacts downwind neighboring countries
driven by the southwesterly winds prevailing from the ICP to YP, the cross-border transport of pollutants was observed along the transport pathway with the lifting plateau topography in YP

causal_relationships.effect: Regional PM2.5 transport to higher altitudes
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: the large PM2.5 contributions of ICP BB emissions lift from the lower altitudes in SR to the higher altitudes in RR for the regional transport of PM2.5

the contributions of regional transport of PM2.5 decrease with the increase in transport distance, reflecting an important role of transport distance between the source–receptor areas in air pollution change

with the predominance of north and northeast winds during the winter period, the long-range transport of air pollutants which emitted from the highly industrialized areas and the intensive fire regions in the southern part of China and Southeast Asia region were likely other important sources for the highly elevated concentrations of PM2.5

causal_relationships.cause: Low wind speed + Low boundary layer height
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: The unfavorable meteorological conditions (lower wind speed and lower boundary layer height) in the winter period were identified as one of the key factors contributing to the high PM2.5 pollution in this period

conditions: Emissions from cement, steel, power plants
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: emissions from stationary sources (i.e., coal burning for cement, steel, and coal-fired power plants in the surrounding provinces of Hanoi) were likely the significant sources of local air pollution through atmospheric transport process during the winter period
when the Northeast Monsoon is prevalent in the dry winter season, there is a high potential of regional transport on the top of the transboundary transport of the pollution

causal_relationships.cause: Low nocturnal boundary layer height + Low wind speed
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: the nocturnal boundary layer height was low (42 m), and wind speed was low (1.4 m/s, daily average) which indicates stagnant atmospheric conditions and supports the accumulation of local pollutants

conditions: Hanoi downwind of Thai Nguyen, Quang Ninh, Bac Ninh, Hung Yen
causal_relationships.evidence_quote: Hanoi is located downwind of several provinces in Northern Vietnam including those having intensive industrial activities, such as Thai Nguyen, Quang Ninh, Bac Ninh, and Hung Yen

synoptic_scale_mechanisms: Northeast Monsoon driving transboundary transport from China
Cold surge onset and persistence affecting PM2.5 levels
El Niño modifying air mass trajectories and pollution sources
Western Pacific Subtropical High transporting Indonesian BB emissions
regional_scale_mechanisms: Regional transport from Northern Vietnam industrial provinces
Wind direction relative to local emission sources
local_scale_mechanisms: Low boundary layer height causing pollutant accumulation
